modules.description: Provides functions to convert error details to strings and parse input from channels or strings into structured row data, handling errors and end-of-file conditions. Works with custom types for errors, locations, rows, headers, and dense or sparse value representations. Used to process structured text input, such as CSV-like data, with precise error reporting and streaming capabilities.

The module provides functions for parsing numerical values, handling quoted strings with escape sequences, and managing token recognition through stateful lexing processes. It operates on Lexing.lexbuf buffers, strings, and file paths, enabling tasks like extracting integers, floating-point numbers, and constructing tokens from input sources. Use cases include processing configuration files, analyzing programming language syntax, and generating structured tokens from raw text inputs.

Parses input streams into structured row and header data using a provided tokenization function. Processes lexing buffers to extract rows and optional headers, working with custom token types to define syntax elements. Used to convert raw text input into typed data structures for further processing.

Provides operations to manipulate and transform lists of values, including dense and sparse representations, and row structures with optional elements. Works with lists of values, pairs of indices and values, and option lists for rows. Used to process structured data in machine learning models and tabular data formats.

Processes CSV data with support for sparse headers and header-less formats, handling irregular row structures. It operates on strings and lists, parsing and transforming input into structured data. Used to import semi-structured data from files or streams where column alignment is inconsistent.

combines input processing, tokenization, and data transformation capabilities, enabling structured parsing of text into rows, headers, and numerical values. It handles error conversion, lexing with stateful token recognition, and manipulation of dense and sparse data structures. Users can extract typed data from CSV-like formats, parse configuration files, and prepare data for analysis or machine learning. Operations include converting errors to messages, recognizing tokens, and transforming list-based data into structured representations.
